metadata.case_name: Appellant (Plaintiff in title suit) v. Respondent

facts.text: Appellant was plaintiff in title suit in Court of Subordinate Judge II, Gaya, seeking declaration that he was nominated Mahant of Moghal Juan Sangat by Guru Mahanth Gulab Das by registered deed dated October 21, 1944, and had right to manage Sangat and off-shoots.
Suit dismissed by trial Judge on May 31, 1947.
Appeal to Patna High Court decided in appellant's favour on November 26, 1951, on condition of paying court fee on amended relief of possession; case remanded to first instance for valuation.

Valuation fixed at Rs. 12,178-4-0 by V. Ramaswami, J. and C.P. Sinha, J.; direction issued for office to calculate deficit court fee, inform counsel, grant 3 months from intimation to pay fee on plaint and memo of appeal, failing which appeal stands dismissed.
High Court office intimation on April 8, 1954, that deficit court fee payable was Rs. 1,987-8-0; time to expire on July 8, 1954.
Appellant unable to pay; advocate requested mention before Vacation Judge on July 8, 1954, for extension, but no Division Bench sitting.
Application filed on July 8, 1954, requesting permission to pay Rs. 1,400 immediately and balance within a month.
Application dismissed by Ramaswami and Ahmad, JJ. on July 13, 1954, holding appeal already stood dismissed by virtue of March 30, 1954 order as amount not paid within time.
Application under s. 151 CPC rejected by Imam, C.J. and Narayan, J. on September 2, 1954; suggested review as proper remedy.
Petition under s. 151 r/w O.47 R.1 CPC filed, stating serious illness, inability to raise loan due to grain market slump; offered to pay within further time fixed by court.
Review application dismissed by Ramaswami and Sinha, JJ. on September 27, 1955; held not under O.47 R.1, ss.148/149 apply only before final disposal, inherent powers not extendable post-final order.
Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court granted by K.K. Banerji and R.K. Chaudhary, JJ.
Respondent did not appear in Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was powerless to enlarge time for payment of deficit court fee, even after peremptorily fixing the period, when application was filed before expiry but considered after.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application for extension filed before time expired; unable to pay due to serious illness and sudden slump in grain market preventing loan.

court_reasoning.text: Application filed before time expired; s.148 allows extension even after expiry, a fortiori before; vacation absence of Division Bench should be considered; peremptory orders are in terrorem, not absolute, courts can take note of events within time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in holding powerless; should have exercised powers under ss.148/149 on July 13, 1954, and inherent powers later.

court_reasoning.text: Sufficient cause made out per application and affidavit; no need to remand as uncontested.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Set aside orders, grant two months for payment.

holdings.text: High Court can extend time under s.148 CPC even after expiry of peremptorily fixed period for court fee payment, especially if application filed before expiry; procedural orders in terrorem do not estop court from considering circumstances.

precedents_cited.relevance: Sentiment should not affect judgment in search for legal principles.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lachmi Narain Marwari v. Balmakund Marwari
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts can restore suit/proceeding despite final order in similar situations to avoid delay but do justice.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: S.148/149 allow time extension even post-expiry; applicable before final order; inherent powers under s.151.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside High Court orders of July 13, 1954, September 2, 1954, and September 27, 1955; held sufficient cause for extension; granted appellant two months from February 7, 1961, to pay deficit court fee of Rs. 1,987-8-0, failing which appeal/suit would stand dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Extension of time to pay deficit court fee; dismissal of appeal and suit set aside conditionally.

key_quotes.text: "I have considerable sympathy towards the plaintiff petitioner who has placed himself in an unfortunate position, but we must be careful not to allow our sympathy to affect our judgment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court expressed sympathy but denied relief erroneously.

key_quotes.text: "Such procedural orders, though peremptory (conditional decrees apart) are, in essence, in terrorem, so that dilatory litigants might put themselves in order and avoid delay."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains nature of peremptory orders, allowing judicial flexibility.
